“Ah! You’re a doubtful person!” laughed Svidrigaïlov. “I told you I didn’t need that money. Can’t you see I’m just trying to be kind? She wasn’t a bad person like some old pawnbroker, was she? Come on, should Luzhin keep living and doing bad things, or should she die? If I don’t help them, Polenka could end up like her.”

He said this with a playful look, watching Raskolnikov, who turned pale and cold when he heard his own words that he had said to Sonia. He quickly stepped back and looked at Svidrigaïlov in shock.

“How do you know?” he whispered, barely able to breathe.

“Well, I live here at Madame Resslich’s, just on the other side of the wall. Kapernaumov is here, and Madame Resslich, an old friend of mine, lives there. I’m a neighbor.”

“You?”

“Yes,” Svidrigaïlov said, shaking with laughter. “I promise you, dear Rodion Romanovitch, that you have really caught my interest. I told you we would become friends, and here we are. You’ll see how easygoing I am. You’ll see that we can get along!”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov reveals his knowledge of Raskolnikov's past actions and expresses a desire to help, highlighting the moral complexities of their situation.
